column9: AP is the abbreviation for action potential, a rapid change in electrical charge across a cell membrane.
column10: The neuroscientist measured the AP frequency to determine the neuron's firing rate.

column9: The propagation of electrical signals through nerve fibers allows the body to respond to stimuli.
column10: Scientists studied the propagation of action potentials along myelinated axons to understand neural communication.

column9: Myelination is the process of forming a myelin sheath around nerve fibers to increase the speed of electrical impulse transmission.
column10: During childhood development, myelination of brain neurons continues into the twenties, affecting cognitive abilities and motor skills.

column9: Saltatory conduction is the rapid propagation of action potentials along myelinated axons where the electrical signal jumps from one node of Ranvier to the next.
column10: The myelin sheath enables saltatory conduction in neurons, allowing nerve impulses to travel up to 100 times faster than in unmyelinated fibers.

column9: Demyelinating disorders are a group of diseases that damage the protective myelin sheath surrounding nerve fibers in the brain and spinal cord.
column10: Multiple sclerosis is one of the most common demyelinating disorders affecting young adults worldwide.

column9: Electrochemical gradients are concentration differences of ions across a membrane that create both electrical and chemical potential energy.
column10: Mitochondria use electrochemical gradients of protons across the inner membrane to drive ATP synthesis during cellular respiration.

column9: Ionic movement refers to the migration of charged atoms or molecules through a medium under the influence of an electric field or concentration gradient.
column10: The ionic movement across the cell membrane is essential for generating action potentials in neurons.

column9: A trivial case is a problem or situation that has an obvious, simple, or uninteresting solution requiring no special techniques.
column10: In proving this theorem, we first handle the trivial case where n equals zero, then proceed to the general case.

column9: Membrane potential is the electrical voltage difference across a cell's plasma membrane due to the separation of charged ions.
column10: The neuron's membrane potential changes from -70 mV to +30 mV during the action potential spike.

column9: ATPase is an enzyme that catalyzes the breakdown of ATP into ADP and phosphate to release energy.
column10: The sodium-potassium ATPase maintains the cell's electrochemical gradient by pumping sodium out and potassium in.

column9: The S-P pump is a cellular membrane protein that actively transports sodium ions out of cells and potassium ions into cells.
column10: The S-P pump maintains the electrical gradient across nerve cell membranes, which is essential for nerve impulse transmission.

column9: An ion pump is a membrane protein that actively transports ions across a cell membrane against their concentration gradient.
column10: The sodium-potassium ion pump maintains the electrical potential across nerve cell membranes by moving three sodium ions out for every two potassium ions moved in.

column9: Depolarization is the process by which a cell membrane's electrical charge becomes less negative or more positive.
column10: During an action potential, sodium channels open and cause rapid depolarization of the neuron's membrane.

column9: Hyperpolarization is the increase in a cell membrane's electrical potential, making it more negative than the resting state.
column10: During neural inhibition, hyperpolarization prevents the neuron from firing an action potential.

column9: A synapse is the junction between two nerve cells where electrical or chemical signals are transmitted.
column10: The neurotransmitters released at the synapse help relay messages from one neuron to the next.

column9: Repolarization is the process by which a cell membrane returns to its resting electrical potential after depolarization.
column10: During cardiac repolarization, potassium ions flow out of the heart muscle cells to restore the negative charge inside.

column9: A chemical gradient is the gradual change in concentration of a substance across a distance or space.
column10: Neurons release neurotransmitters that create a chemical gradient, allowing signals to travel from one cell to another.

column9: Intracellular processes occur inside the cell membrane.
column10: The intracellular concentration of calcium ions regulates muscle contraction.

column9: The concentration of a substance is the amount of it contained in a particular volume of liquid or gas.
column10: The concentration of salt in seawater varies between 3.3% and 3.7% depending on location.

column9: A phospholipid is a type of lipid molecule that contains a phosphate group and forms the main component of cell membranes.
column10: The phospholipid bilayer of the cell membrane regulates which substances can enter and exit the cell.

column9: A bilayer is a structure consisting of two layers of molecules, especially in cell membranes.
column10: The cell membrane's phospholipid bilayer acts as a barrier between the inside and outside of the cell.

column9: Mammalian characteristics include warm blood, hair or fur, and the ability to produce milk for offspring.
column10: The mammalian brain has evolved complex structures for processing emotions and social behaviors.

column1: Canonical ionic distributions - 典型离子分布
column9: Canonical ionic distributions refer to the standard or most representative patterns of ion concentrations across cellular membranes or within specific biological compartments.
column10: The researchers used computational models to predict canonical ionic distributions in neurons under different physiological conditions.

column1: Graded (Passive) potentials - 分级（被动）电位
column9: Graded (Passive) potentials are electrical responses in neurons that vary in magnitude proportionally to the strength of the stimulus and decrease with distance from the stimulus site.
column10: The dendrites of sensory neurons generate graded (passive) potentials that must reach a threshold before triggering an action potential at the axon hillock.

column9: The threshold potential is the critical level of depolarization that a membrane potential must reach to trigger an action potential in a neuron or muscle cell.
column10: When the sodium ions rush into the cell and the membrane reaches the threshold potential of approximately -55mV, the neuron fires an action potential.

column9: The aircraft will overshoot the runway if the pilot doesn't reduce speed immediately.
column10: The economy tends to overshoot its target growth rate during periods of excessive stimulus.

column9: The aircraft began to undershoot the runway due to insufficient thrust during the final approach.
column10: The pilot had to apply full throttle when he realized the plane would undershoot the intended landing zone by several hundred feet.

column9: The car began to drift sideways on the icy road.
column10: During the race, the driver expertly let his vehicle drift through the sharp corner.

column1: V-G ion channels - 电压门控离子通道
column9: V-G ion channels are transmembrane proteins that open or close in response to changes in membrane potential, allowing specific ions to flow across the cell membrane.
column10: The action potential is generated when V-G ion channels rapidly open, causing sodium ions to rush into the neuron.

column9: A gastropod is a mollusk that typically has a single coiled shell and moves by means of a muscular foot on its underside.
column10: The garden snail is a common gastropod that can damage vegetable crops by eating the leaves.

column9: Nodes of Ranvier are regularly spaced gaps in the myelin sheath along nerve fibers where action potentials are regenerated.
column10: The speed of nerve impulse conduction increases because the signal jumps from one node of Ranvier to the next in a process called saltatory conduction.

column9: Saltatory conduction is the rapid transmission of nerve impulses that jumps from one node of Ranvier to the next along myelinated axons.
column10: The myelin sheath enables saltatory conduction, allowing electrical signals to travel up to 100 times faster than in unmyelinated fibers.

column9: Pathologies are the scientific studies of diseases and the structural and functional changes they cause in the body.
column10: The medical students spent hours reviewing different pathologies to prepare for their diagnostic exam.

column9: An autoimmune condition occurs when the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its own healthy tissues.
column10: Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease that causes inflammation in the joints.

column9: Multiple sclerosis is a chronic autoimmune disease that damages the protective covering of nerve fibers in the brain and spinal cord.
column10: Her multiple sclerosis diagnosis came after years of experiencing unexplained numbness and fatigue.

column1: Guillain-barré syndrome - 格林－巴利综合征
column9: Guillain-Barré syndrome is a rare neurological disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the peripheral nerves, causing muscle weakness and sometimes paralysis.
column10: The patient was diagnosed with Guillain-Barré syndrome after experiencing progressive weakness in both legs following a respiratory infection.
